`System.IO.FileAttributes` is an enum type:
```
 > [enum]::GetValues([io.FileAttributes]) | % { '{0,-17}: {1}' -f $_, [int]$_ }
ReadOnly         : 1
Hidden           : 2
System           : 4
Directory        : 16
Archive          : 32
Device           : 64
Normal           : 128
Temporary        : 256
SparseFile       : 512
ReparsePoint     : 1024
Compressed       : 2048
Offline          : 4096
NotContentIndexed: 8192
Encrypted        : 16384
IntegrityStream  : 32768
NoScrubData      : 131072
```
2 + 2 = 4 (system)

Adding to the above you are not meant to add or subtract flag enums together as that causes invalid values. While the raw value is an integer which is why `+=` and `-=` just adds or subtracts the value of that flag it won't result in the same value. You should use `-bor` to add flags and `-band -bnot` to remove flags;

```powershell
[IO.FileAttributes]::Directory -bor [IO.FileAttributes]::Hidden

[IO.FileAttributes]"Directory, Hidden" -band -bnot [IO.FileAttributes]::Hidden
```

In these examples `Hidden` is equal to `0x2` and `Directory` is equal to `0x10`

```
# Hex == Binary == Decimal
0x02 == 0000 0010 == 2
0x10 == 0001 0000 == 16

# Bitwise OR will set bits that are present in both the LHS and RHS
0001 0000 -bor 0000 0010 == 0001 0010 == 0x12 == 18

# Bitwise AND will set bits only present in both sides
# Bitwise NOT will reverse the bits of its RHS
# Combine both together and you can remove a flag
-bnot 0000 0010 == 1111 1101 == 0xFFFFFFFD == -3
0001 0010 -band 1111 1101 == 0001 0000 == 0x10 == 16
```

The beauty of bitwise operations is you can run them multiple times as they operate on the bits set rather than addition or subtraction which always adds or removes the value.
I'm sorry, but from my perspective as a user and casual script writer, if this simple operation corrupts the file system that is definitely wrong and definitely a bug.

From a perspective of a casual/new to PowerShell/Programming script writer I can somewhat sympathize but using bitwise operations is how this stuff is done. You can't really use general addition/subtraction on these values and while it works in some cases it will most likely cause problems.

To me this is a feature request to have `+=` and `-=` act like the bitwise operators for `[Flags]` based enums which I'm unsure whether PowerShell could or could not do. It's not a bug as it's working as intended but it might be a good idea to implement such a functionality to help people new to this concept going forward.

In this particular case, how would you even know that any of this involves bits, and why would you care? The interface is adding a string attribute to a file. And since there is no modifying operator for `-bor`, the "correct" way to do this would be something like this:

```powershell
$attr = (gi -fo foo).attributes; (gi -fo foo).attributes = $attr -bor 'hidden';
```

which is extremely tedious for what should be the extremely simple operation of making a file hidden.

There is probably a nicer way to do this that I don't know, but it will probably also suck.

Also I have to say that I'm probably not the only person offended by the quick marking of everything in this project as a "question" even when the answer is far from adequate.

> The interface is adding a string attribute to a file.

It's not really a string, that's sort of a case of PowerShell already making it a bit easier behind the scenes.  The string is converted to a call like `[IO.FileAttributes]::Parse('hidden')` by the binder.
 
> which is extremely tedious for what should be the extremely simple operation of making a file hidden.

It is a simple operation, but it doesn't come up often. It'd be nice to have a `-bor` and `-band` assignment operator but outside of this it probably wouldn't get a lot of use.

> In this particular case, how would you even know that any of this involves bits, and why would you care? 

When it's an enum with flags (an enum with multiple values) then it will use bits. While I know `Attributes` itself is an enum this because I've dealt with it before you can determine this dynamically

```powershell
> Get-Item $pwd.Path | Get-Member -Name Attributes

   TypeName: System.IO.DirectoryInfo

Name       MemberType Definition
----       ---------- ----------
Attributes Property   System.IO.FileAttributes Attributes {get;set;}
```

I can see it's not a string and by deduction based on the purpose I can usually come to the conclusion it's an enum. When in doubt a quick check online on [System.IO.FileAttributes](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.io.fileattributes?view=net-5.0) type or doing `$obj.Attributes -is [Enum]` tells me definitively.

> And since there is no modifying operator for -bor, the "correct" way to do this would be something like this:

In your particular use case you need to pass it by type rather than just the string

```powershell
$file = Get-Item -Path foo -Force
$file.Attributes = $file.Attributes -bor [IO.FileAttributes]"Hidden"
```

This is because bitwise operations work on numerical values and the operator doesn't know how to cast the string to the possible enum on the LHS. I say possible here because it's perfectly valid to had both the LHS and RHS as just integer fields and not an enum.

The only thing I find that sucks is that you need to do `$obj.Attributes = $obj.Attributes -bor` rather than the equivalent to `+=` (in bitwise terms other languages use `|=` to bitwise OR and set at the same time. For example in C# you can do the following to replicate adding and removing a flag (what `-bor` and `-band -bnot` does) to an existing value:

```csharp
file.Attributes |= FileAttributes.Hidden
file.Attributes &= ~FileAttributes.Hidden
```
But in PowerShell this isn't possible today which can be annoying.

> Also I have to say that I'm probably not the only person offended by the quick marking of everything in this project as a "question" even when the answer is far from adequate.

Let me preface the following by saying I am no way affiliated with Microsoft or the PowerShell team and am just a community user of PowerShell who tries to help out where I can.

First off I am sorry that this your experience and can totally understand how closing issue reports quickly can bring across a negative experience. On the flip side you have to understand that this repository is very large with a lot of issues being reported and thus is is very important to try and filter out what are bugs and what might just be misunderstandings or general questions. 

Now this comes to the tricky question of what constitutes a bug and while you may think it is a bug because it doesn't do what you expect the truth of the matter is this is the expected behaviour based on the code shared and there is a proper method to achieve what you want. Personally I would think this is a feature request but even then I am doubtful it would be implemented as this could break existing code that might rely on the current `+=` and `-=` behaviour. PowerShell as a whole is mostly adverse to making breaking changes (5 -> 6 jump being abnormal). An alternative is having 2 methods `AddFlag` and `RemoveFlag` that could do this but you still need the assignment on the LHS so you only really gain a slightly simpler interface.

I apologise for being blunt but in the end this repo has 3000+ issues and I think getting an actual reponse, even if it's a no or working as intended, is better than receiving nothing at all or having it just left to stagnate over time with no action at all.

> This is the recommended method of setting and removing the `hidden` attribute on a file

Where is this method recommended?

I agree that the way PowerShell presents the `FileAttributes` enum makes it easy to get the impression that `$File.Attributes += <attribute>` is an idempotent operation.  C# doesn't allow explicitly overloading `+=` or `-=`; I haven't checked yet whether PowerShell follows suit.  Since modifying the behavior of those operators would be a breaking change in any case, how about adding `AddAttribute` and `RemoveAttribute` script methods to `FileInfo` objects?

Regardless, I will continue to do PowerShell related work.

As for this particular issue, making `+=` / `-=` overloadable on specific types would not be a breaking change. And

```powershell
$attributes += 'attribute'
```

has the semantic meaning of adding an attribute, the implementation is irrelevant. If such an interface corrupts your filesystem, that is very bad.

As for the problem of making files hidden or not hidden on Windows, the best solution right now is:

```powershell
attrib +h file
attrib -h file
```
.

Linux does not have hidden files, so portability is not an issue.

@dwtaber Thank you for looking into this. > in reply to me asking where += and -= operations were recommended for FileInfo.Attributes? Both of those sources discuss performing bitwise operations. Let me explain my motivation and reasoning here. I am not an advanced PowerShell user, I never read a book and just learned from experimentation and looking up bits of info on the internet. So I googled "powershell make file hidden" and the result that came up was: https://social.technet.microsoft.com/Forums/en-US/33665b03-d383-41ed-a836-fd83c217b3f1/making-files-hidden-with-powershell?forum=ITCG which gave me this syntax. Out of curiosity, I tried using this syntax on an already hidden file and noticed the behavior I reported. Now, consider this from the perspective of a C++ programmer. I do some C++ although I'm by no means very good at it. The operation: ```powershell $attributes += 'attribute' ``` is **ALREADY** overloaded to take a string. No reasonable person would expect such an operation with a string on the RHS to be arithmetic addition to a bitmask. If only numeric values were allowed, this would be far more obvious. So while it's no surprise that the code on an internet forum was wrong, it looked completely fine to me. I'm glad you see my perspective here.
Making files hidden with powershell

Why do not just set attributes you want? This is a one time task.
```
(Get-Item file -Force).Attributes = 34   # Hidden, Archive
(Get-Item file -Force).Attributes = 32   # Archive
```

@237dmitry the issue here is that string values are allowed and they do not exhibit the behavior a user would expect.

As for setting a file hidden, it's far easier to just use the `attrib` command, at least with the current state of things.

> @237dmitry the issue here is that string values are allowed and they do not exhibit the behavior a user would expect.

In PowerShell there is an expectation that for a binary expression, the RHS is converted implicitly to the same type as the LHS.  There's also an expectation that conversion paths are a lot more forgiving, for example an implicit conversion my call a static `Parse` method if it exists (like in the case of an enum).

I can definitely agree that adding two bit flag enum values together can be very unintuitive if you don't know that's what it is doing. That said, being able to use string values as short hand for enum values is a feature that is heavily depended on. This is one of the very few instances where it's slightly problematic.
